captions.text: Camera Woman: Just give me a minute. I'm going to get the camera setup.
ACLU Voting Rights Attorney Dale Ho: Thanks a lot for agreeing to be our celebrity ambassador on voting rights Lewis.
We'll try to make this photo shoot as painless as possible. (Slide Says: Behind the Scenes At ACLU Photo Shoot.)
Lewis Black: Well no photo shoot is painless, but I'm happy to help; it's important.

I mean who is denying people the right to vote.
Dale Ho: You'd be surprised. We're fighting

people trying to suppress voting all over
the country. Like North Carolina. They slashed

a week of early voting. That affects over
two million people.
Camera Woman: All right, if I could get you guys to look at the lens.

Lewis Black: Why stop people from voting early?
Dale Ho: Well, early voting makes it easier

to vote, and that can decide an election.
Here, this is a picture that I carry around
with me everywhere I go in case I get a chance to talk about early voting. Look at that line.

Lewis Black: What the hell is that? Is it
Black Friday? I mean you'd think that the

people of Florida would want their voters
to like, you know vote? What's next, a poll tax?

Dale Ho: Well ...
Lewis Black: Oh no fucking way!
Camera Woman: All right guys, if I can just have you look into the lens.
Dale Ho: Voter ID like they tried to implement in Wisconsin, costs money.
It essentially is a poll tax, and look at what they make Wisconsinites do just get one of these ID cards.

Camera Woman: Um ...
Dale Ho: (Pointing a Flow Chart) This is an actual document from the
state of Wisconsin which is supposed to show how easy it is to get an ID.
Lewis Black: This looks like a chart showing how tough it is for sperm to find a fertilized egg,

which explains why it's so tired when
it finally gets there.

Camera Woman: Ah guys?
Lewis Black: Elected officials shouldn't get

to choose who gets to choose elected officials!
Look, people marched, and fought, and died
for the right to vote, and they want to legislate away that sacrifice to stay in power!? Not on my watch baby!
Camera Woman: Ah, if I could um ...
Lewis Black: Take the picture!
Slide Says: Not on my watch, baby. Join the Fight at ACLU.org

title: Lewis Black Says F#%! Voter Suppression

comments.author: Luft Hans

comments.text:
Voter ID's which are only offered at certain times at certain places and 
require payment of a fee or payment of a fee for other documents needed to 
get the ID is voter suppression. Having State Troopers intimidate people 
attempting to get voter IDs is voter suppression. Sending out purposefully 
deceptive mailers only to Democrats is voter suppression. Sending 
organizations with documented histories of illegal activities like "True 
the Vote" to polling places to intimidate voters is voter suppression. 
Using a program like Checkpoint in 21 states to purge voters from voting 
lists is voter suppression and a major felony. 40k voter registrations 
missing in Georgia and a Secretary of State who says he has no obligation 
to accept any registrations he doesn't want to is voter suppression. 
Moreover, most of this is felonious activity. Voter suppression is real and 
it's the main reason the GOP swept so much. Anyone who denies it's real is 
cognitively dissonant, being paid to say it's not real, or guilty of it. 
(Like this SOS John Galt below.) ﻿

Love Lewis Black as a comedian, but why should anyone be influenced by him 
any more than any other celebrity? Clowns are for making us laugh and no

subject. This clip is a smokescreen to obfuscate the simple fact that 
liberals want people to 'vote early and vote often'.  What is wrong with 
requiring an ID to vote? We are allowed just ONE vote you know, and only 
citizens are allowed to vote. The effort put forth by these people would be 
better used to help the handful of people needing IDs to get them. Wear 
your Bull-Shit filter for this clip.﻿

anything close to exceptional or freedom?

In the US electoral system in 2014, a fraudulent vote appears about once in 
every 30 million legitimate votes.  When legislators use "voter fraud" as a 
pretense for #voterid to make voting next to impossible for millions of 
voters, this is #votersuppression .  It's politics at its most debased, and

comments.author: Annatala Wolf

comments.text:
It is not a mistake to beat the stolen election drum when you read the 
article Kennedy wrote.  

1. Ohio didn't meet the metrics that we use to measure the fairness of an 
election in a foreign country.

2. We measure the vulnerability of a system based on 3 major factors: how 
many people, how much time and how complex. The Diabold voting machine 
results could be changed by one person in a matter of seconds. Plus because 
they did not contain an audit mechanism the tampering could not be 
detected. Anyone with access to the computer could change the results.

And that's just the tip of the iceberg. There were many other 
"Irregularities". And this by a company that makes ATM machines whose CEO 
said he'd deliver Ohio for Bush.

If you have a subscription to Rolling Stone you can read it here.
http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/10432334/was_the_2004_election_stolen
comments.author: Tom Lynch

comments.text:
+Tom Lynch I think it's a mistake to beat the "stolen election" drum. 
 Anyone who comes so close to losing that minor irregularities could lead 
to it, deserves to lose.  The future, however, is a different matter.
comments.author: Annatala Wolf

comments.text:
Robert Kennedy, "Was the 2004 Election Stolen?", Rolling Stone 
Magazine, June 15, 2006 

Too bad the article is no longer on line. Had complete directions on how to 
hack a Diabold voting machine. The voting machine system used an 
unencripted, unpassword protected Access Database to store the results.

comments.text:

comments.author: Annatala Wolf

comments.text:
Voter fraud is the least efficient way to steal an election. To be 
successful you need it to be easy, undetectable and to not be caught. To 
use voter fraud you would need a large number of people to cast enough 
votes to change the results of an election. The more people involved in an 
illegal activity the more likely it will be discovered. 

If you want to steal an election, having a corrupt tallying system is more 
effective. Less people needed (only a few).

comments.text:
U.S. District Judge Nelva Gonzales Ramos issued a permanent injunction 
against the state's strict voter ID law on the grounds that it places too 
great a burden on African American and Latinos. She also said it was 
imposed with an unconstitutional purpose, violates the Equal Protection 
clause, is a poll tax and a violation of the Voting Rights Act. 
#votersuppression  ﻿
comments.author: Sean Cook

comments.text:
The Constitution is clear as day: no poll tax or other tax can be required 
before voting (Amendment XXIV). This includes any fees required to get a 
state-issued ID -- including fees for papers required to prove citizenship. 
If states want to require an ID for voting, they have to provide it, FREE 
of charge (and free of hassle) to all citizens living in the state -- 
anything else is unconstitutional.﻿

comments.text: Voting is the one most important thing a citizen can do.  It is more important than driving, traveling, or getting a subsidy or entitlement.  Yet we don't require ID for the first, but do for all the latter.  Your puppet masters require you to prove who you are in order to get things, but don't in order to "elect" the puppets they give you to select from.       Think about it.
comments.author: Christy Sandhoff

comments.text:

their multiple voting schemes.  STRONG voter ID laws will stop the dems 
from the fraud they commit every Nov.

comments.text:
+Greg Mee lol just a slight problem with your theory....VOTER FRAUD ISNT 
HAPPENING! In fact, every time the GOP is given a chance to prove it they

comments.author: Eric M

comments.text:
+David Foster  lmao id counter with the claim for the need for new voting 
ID laws is BASED on conspiracy theories! You seem to be missing the point. 
This isnt about "security", its about ONE PARTY changing the rules KNOWING 
it will HELP them in future elections. Go back and look up Heritage founder 
1980, where Paul Weyrich declared "We dont want everyone to vote". They 
know low turn outs help them, while large turn outs generally equal defeat 
for Republicans. Like I said, PROVE the need for tougher voting laws BEFORE 
taking away a SINGLE Americans right to vote!! smh and they call themselves 
"the freedom party"?! smh Lincoln would not be a party to this
comments.author: Eric M

comments.text:
We don't need conspiracy theories, +Eric M But all you have said, is that 
it isn't necessary. It isn't evil to insist on a bit of security.
comments.author: David Foster

comments.text:
+David Foster because driving isnt a right, and neither is welfare. You 
have to apply for both. Voting rights are on a much grander scale. How 
about just proving the system is flawed, other than by GOP losses? Since, 
the timing coincides with recent Presidential election losses in the states 
doing this, all "battleground" states. Personally, I wonder why, in the 
craze for a scandal, this has been largely overlooked. One party, changing 
the rules, that just happens to benefit them, in hotly contested 
states..and no one from the right bats an eye?! PS the claims of "rampant 
voter fraud" have been debunked time and again, including by members of the 
GOP when they tried to prove the need for it! Example: Iowa's AG did a two 
year study to prove illegals voted. He found 5 instances of voter fraud 
instead, all felons who voted before their rights were restored. Which I 
might add, is the most common form of voter fraud (per numerous studies)
comments.author: Eric M

comments.text:
I hear that claim a lot, but if we insist on ID for mundane things like 
Driver Licenses or Welfare, then what is the problem? Why the opposition? 
If nothing else, you could just remove any doubt of scandal.

comments.author: Greg Mee

comments.text:
The whole voter-fraud issue is a lot like the concept of digital rights 
management. The people committing the crimes will find a way to do it 
regardless and in the mean time actual people who want to play a game/watch 
a movie/listen to music-VOTE will have to suffer though it. In fact, there 
are some people who download "cracks" for games they already own just to be 
able to play them without DRM. That could also translate to voting because 
we might have actual citizens who are sick of all the red tape and turn to 
counterfeit voter-IDs just to avoid the hassle, or just not vote at all.
As for the issue of early-voting. We live in a busy world with lots of 
people and a lot of those people are working all day and of course a lot of 
jobs let out around the same time so there's going to be a rush of people 
at the voting booths and you're tired, just wanting to go home and relax 
but you really want to vote. In a way it's better not to think of it so 
much as early voting as just an extended period of time to let people vote.﻿

comments.author: Jeremy Duncan

comments.text:
(Not seen vid)
In Austria, every citizen is obliged to register where the main living 
address is. Therefore, every voter is registered automatically and gets the 
information about the next ballot regardless if interested or not. To 
participate, you go to the polling station mentioned in that information - 
usually at your nearest school. The end.

Why this probably wouldn't work in the US: Too many people fearing that if 
they register where they live the MiB will get them, and crying fascism at 
the very idea of mandatory registration.
comments.author: Andreas Habicher

comments.text:
To the people saying just go out and vote on voting day, and the people 
saying "ermehgerd people can't get off work":
How about you quit arguing, and work TOGETHER so you both get a win.

Limit early voting to an amount less than 50, because it is going to be 
needed because it IS true that our country hasn't the resources (or 
willpower) to all vote at once on one day, but I agree 50 is probably too 
much. MORE importantly, let's get election day to be a FEDERAL holiday 
REQUIRING all business to be closed, or at least incredibly limited hours, 
in order to allow people to go vote?

Make it a holiday like Mother's day, as in the first or second Wednesday of 
November. That way it is always in mid-week, so those arguing they'd abuse 
it just for a day off instead of voting are limited, due to it being mid 
work-week, and it is on a federally recognized day, so it spreads awareness 
and reminders to people, to go friggin' vote because in instances like 
mid-terms, people simply just forget.

Quit fighting with one another, be REAL patriots of your country, and work 
together to help improve the lives of your fellow Americans instead of 
scream which one of you is the bigger retard because they don't believe the 
same things you do.﻿
comments.author: NiffNozzletoff
